diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems including the skin (e.g., psoriasiform rash), cardiovascular system (e.g., acute pericarditis and pericardial effusion), and central nervous system (e.g., seizures).

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Associated with psoriasis and can occasionally lead to systemic manifestations including pericarditis; seizures are less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause carditis, including pericarditis and effusion, and can have a rash, though typically not psoriasiform. Seizures are rare but can occur if there are central nervous system involvements.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A granulomatous disease that can cause skin lesions similar to psoriasis, neurosarcoidosis (which may present as seizures), and cardiac involvement including pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Drug-Induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain drugs can induce a lupus-like syndrome marked by features such as pericarditis and skin rash; seizures are less common.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting the heart valves, it can lead to systemic manifestations including rash and, rarely, seizures due to embolic phenomena; pericarditis may occur though it's less common.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause pericarditis and a range of neurological symptoms, including seizures; skin manifestations can occur, though a psoriasiform rash is less typical.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A multisystem inflammatory disorder that can cause skin lesions, including those similar to psoriasis, and complications such as pericarditis; neurological involvement can lead to seizures.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease can present with features of systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including skin rashes, pericarditis, and occasionally seizures.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Encephalitis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily a cause of seizures and other neurological symptoms, it can be associated with systemic inflammation, including rash and rarely, pericarditis.

diagnoses: Systemic Vasculitis, such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
Infectious Endocarditis with immune complex deposition
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)
Schizophrenia (in the context of considering psychosis separately)
Autoimmune Diseases such as Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis in rare autoimmune contexts)
Hemolytic Anemia Secondary to Autoimmune Disease
Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) with Secondary Autoimmune Complications
Infectious mononucleosis due to Epstein-Barr virus
Schizophrenia (and other primary psychotic disorders, considered if other causes are ruled out)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Primary Vasculitis Syndromes (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with synovitis, fever, alopecia, acute pericarditis, and pleural effusion among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for joint involvement (synovitis), RA can also have systemic manifestations including fever, pericarditis, and pleural effusion. Alopecia is less common but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: This condition can involve the skin (leading to alopecia), joints (synovitis), heart (pericarditis), and pleura (effusion), though fever is less commonly a direct result of the disease itself.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD presents with features of several autoimmune diseases including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, and can include symptoms of synovitis, fever, alopecia, pericarditis, and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: In addition to muscular and dermatological symptoms, dermatomyositis can feature inflammatory involvement of the heart (pericarditis) and lungs (pleural effusion), with possible alopecia and fever.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.rationale: This vasculitis can lead to multiple organ systems being affected, including the heart (pericarditis) and lungs (pleural effusion), as well as causing fever and, less commonly, alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Lupus pernio (Sarcoidosis)
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting the lungs, sarcoidosis can lead to systemic symptoms such as fever and less commonly involves the heart (pericarditis), pleura (effusion), and skin (alopecia through skin involvement).

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory disease can cause a characteristic rash, fever, and joint pain (synovitis), and can involve the heart (pericarditis) and lungs (pleural effusion).

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Although more classically associated with heart valve infections, infectious endocarditis can lead to systemic symptoms including fever, and in severe cases, can cause pleural effusion. Alopecia, pericarditis, and synovitis are less classic but possible.

diagnoses.name: Whipple's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare bacterial infection that can lead to systemic symptoms including fever; joint involvement, including synovitis; and potentially heart and lung complications, though alopecia is not typically reported.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, characterized by pain and swelling in the joints. Psoriatic arthritis can lead to onychodystrophy, poor healing, and systemic features can include conditions like thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect nearly any part of the body, manifesting in wide-ranging symptoms such as rash, joint pain, and kidney problems. Memory problems can occur, as well as increased risk of pneumonia due to weakened immune response.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also involve other tissues and organs, leading to a wide array of symptoms including poor healing and systemic complications like thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that result in hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. Complications can include lung involvement (e.g., pneumonia), vascular abnormalities leading to poor healing, and various systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition can cause a variety of symptoms including memory problems, poor healing, and potentially neurological complications. Associated hematologic abnormalities could obscurely relate to thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloproliferative Neoplasm
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders characterized by the overproduction of blood cells by the bone marrow, often leading to thrombocytosis. Complications and associated conditions can include an increased risk of infections like pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus, if untreated, progresses to AIDS, which is characterized by a weakened immune system leading to severe infections like pneumonia, memory problems, and various dermatologic conditions including nail dystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes inflammation of blood vessels, potentially affecting any organ in the body. While primarily affecting the respiratory system, it can result in systemic symptoms like poor wound healing and is associated with thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period. It can lead to numerous complications such as poor wound healing, an increased risk of infections like pneumonia, and may indirectly contribute to memory issues through vascular disease.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A common thyroid disorder marked by decreased hormone production, which can affect metabolic rate and lead to symptoms including poor healing, and, in severe cases, myxedema coma, which can present with altered mental status or memory issues.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Symptoms may include skin hyperelasticity, joint hypermobility, easy bruising, and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, potentially leading to aneurysms, particularly in the aorta, as well as features that can include long limbs and fingers, heart problems, and lens dislocation.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by low levels of clotting protein in the blood. Symptoms may include easy bruising, nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and in women, heavy menstrual bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Symptoms might include muscle pain and difficulty concentrating ('fibro fog').

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Symptoms can include menstrual irregularity, excess hair growth, acne, and obesity.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Loeys-Dietz Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by the aggressive formation of aneurysms in various arteries throughout the body. It may also feature skeletal manifestations and skin abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes numerous cysts to grow in the kidneys. This condition can cause flank pain and can lead to kidney failure. Aneurysms in the brain are a known complication.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Symptoms include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A painful disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus — the endometrium — grows outside your uterus. It can cause dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Oral Cavity

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV/AIDS can present a wide range of symptoms such as increased susceptibility to infections due to its impact on the immune system, rashes, and mood changes. Anxiety and mood lability can be both direct and indirect effects of the disease or its treatment.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems, presenting with rashes (especially the butterfly rash), increased susceptibility to infections, mood lability, and anxiety. Obstructive sleep apnea is not directly associated but can occur due to related conditions like obesity.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
diagnoses.reasoning: Patients with CKD might experience a plethora of nonspecific symptoms including increased susceptibility to infections and rashes. Anxiety and mood lability can be related to the stress of managing a chronic condition. Although less direct, CKD can be associated with obstructive sleep apnea, especially in advanced stages.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Diabetes, particularly when poorly controlled, can lead to increased susceptibility to infections and might present skin manifestations such as rashes. Anxiety and mood swings can be associated with fluctuations in blood glucose levels. Obstructive sleep apnea is more common in diabetic individuals, often related to obesity.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypothyroidism can lead to a variety of symptoms including mood lability and anxiety. Patients might also experience skin changes like dry skin and rashes and have a higher vulnerability to infections. The association with obstructive sleep apnea is primarily due to the potential for weight gain.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Cushing's syndrome is characterized by high cortisol levels, which can cause mood lability, anxiety, increased susceptibility to infections due to immune suppression, and various skin changes including rashes. Obstructive sleep apnea can occur in Cushing's syndrome due to weight gain associated with the condition.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: These disorders directly increase susceptibility to infections and can have various presentations, including skin issues like rashes. Anxiety and mood lability can be secondary to living with a chronic disease. Direct association with obstructive sleep apnea is rare but can occur due to secondary factors.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Lymphoma can cause increased susceptibility to infections due to immune system involvement, rashes, and anxiety or mood changes either as direct symptoms or secondary to disease burden. Obstructive sleep apnea may be seen in lymphoma patients, potentially due to lymphoid tissue growth or treatment effects.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Sarcoidosis involves granulomas affecting multiple organs which can explain rashes, increased susceptibility to infections due to immune response alterations, mood lability, and anxiety. The relationship with obstructive sleep apnea is not direct but may occur due to sarcoidosis-related lung involvement or secondary complications.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.reasoning: Though primarily a neurologic condition, MS can have systemic effects including increased susceptibility to infections due to immunomodulatory treatments, mood lability, and anxiety. Skin rashes can occur but are less common. MS itself is not a direct cause of obstructive sleep apnea, but fatigue and sleep disturbances are common in MS.

diagnoses: Secondary immunodeficiency (e.g., due to chronic disease or medication)
Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) or Prostate Issues
Vitamin Deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin C deficiency leading to scurvy, which can cause easy bruising and skin changes)
Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (particularly types that affect blood vessels could theoretically lead to easy bruising)
Skin Tags (if 'tags' refers to this condition)
Presbyopia or other Refractive Vision Errors
Myocardial Infarction (as a differential for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy)
Pilocystic Astrocytoma (for cysts with neurological relevance)
Neurogenic Bladder (leading to incontinence in relation to other symptoms)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation due to allergic reaction
Staphylococcal or Streptococcal Toxic Shock Syndromes
Multiple Sclerosis (considering incontinence and potential CNS involvement)
Atrophic Vaginitis (considering incontinence in postmenopausal women)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Asthma exacerbation (if history of asthma with new triggers)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Brain Tumor, particularly in the posterior fossa region
Vascular Malformation in the brain, such as arteriovenous malformation

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances (scintillation) followed by a migraine headache, which can also include nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back part of the brain, causing symptoms like vertigo, dizziness, numbness, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it temporarily blocks blood flow to the brain, causing various neurological symptoms including headache, numbness, and visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
diagnoses.description: A disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear, leading to brief episodes of vertigo (sense of spinning) that may be accompanied by nausea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing severe dizziness (vertigo), ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness or congestion in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal cell growth within the brain exhibiting symptoms like headache, vomiting, seizures, numbness, and visual disturbances depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the brain and spinal cord, leading to numbness, weakness, balance issues, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted, causing brain tissue to be deprived of oxygen and nutrients, leading to symptoms such as numbness, headache, and difficulty seeing.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to infection, causing symptoms such as headache, vomiting, fever, numbness, and visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Some specific syndromes or seizure types can cause aura, including visual disturbances, vertigo, and other sensory changes.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness, headache, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a minibar, a temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing similar symptoms to a stroke but usually resolves within 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause a variety of symptoms depending on the tumor's location, including headache, weakness, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain itself, often due to infection, causing headache, fever, confusion, and in severe cases, seizures and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include weakness, tingling, and in some cases, speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, fever, and speech problems.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissue covering it. Symptoms can include a sudden, severe headache, weakness, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Aphasia can be a symptom if the electrical disturbance occurs in language areas of the brain.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves neurological phenomena (aura), such as visual disturbances or speech disturbances, followed by a severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A subtype of migraine that involves visual disturbances (scintillation) and other neurological symptoms that appear shortly before or during the headache.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by dull, aching head pain, and tightness or pressure across the forehead or on the sides and back of the head.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: Severe, debilitating pain on one side of the head, often around the eye, with attacks occurring in clusters over weeks or months.

diagnoses.name: Medication Overuse Headache
diagnoses.description: Headaches resulting from chronic and excessive use of medication to treat headache symptoms, leading to a cycle of recurring headaches.

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinuses that can cause a headache, usually accompanied by fever, and facial pressure or pain.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain, often presenting with headaches, nausea, vomiting, and neurological disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, leading to fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: Low blood sugar, which can cause symptoms such as headache, weakness, trembling, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, leading to fatigue, weakness, and potentially headaches.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (only for psychosis if other diagnoses are excluded)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
DRESS Syndrome (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Hepatitis B or C associated Nephropathy
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
HIV/AIDS (can present with various hematologic and neurologic manifestations)
Infectious diseases (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C)
